dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The National Anthem resounds over the precision maneuvers the Navy’s Blue Angels. When Old Glory fills the frame th local announcer identifies the station, signifies the megahertz and signs off for the morning. Transmission end and a BLAST of disturbing static rules the airwaves. It i 2:30am on a Sunday morning.

dialogues.speaker: CAMERA SLOWLY WITHDRAWS
dialogues.text: The TV set appears. A fireplace is off to the right, trop of outstanding achievement in annual home sales on the mantel; STEVEN FREELING asleep in his convertible chair, open briefcase on his lap, real estate maps and lease contracts spread out on the floor by his stocking feet. CAMERA CONTINUES TO WITHDRAW until we are moving out of t living room of this suburban two-story home and up the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAMERA MOVES along the hallway, past the guest bath and o to a partially open door. We explore this room, if only f an instant, to catch DIANE FREELING, 32, tossing in her sleep, a tangle of hair covering her face. INT. DANA’S BEDROOM - NIGHT 3 CAMERA moves away and slithers into another bedroom. DIAN FREELING is sixteen, very beautiful, and snoring unevenly She is surrounded by potato chips and homework. INT. CHILDREN’S BEDROOM - NIGHT 4 The SOUND OF TELEVISION STATIC leaks as the CAMERA moves the last bedroom. ROBBIE FREELING is just a seven-year-ol lump under the covers. With the sheets tucked around him, looks like a ghost and where his head should be there is Dodgers baseball cap. The closet light is on and the clos opened only a crack to let in the safe night light as we beyond Robbie to CAROL ANNE FREELING. The STATIC SOUNDS f the 0.S. TV seem to arouse this pert six-years-old froma sound and regular sleep. Her eyes snap open. She listens flicks some sleep from her eyes, and rises out of bed.  CAMERA TRACKS AHEAD OF HER as if drawing her OUTSIDE the safety of her bedroom and roommate brother.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The STATIC crackles louder and a BLUE GLOW dawns across C Anne. She could be sleepwalking. Her eyes are riveted and breathing quickens. The STATIC BOOMS now and Carol Anne s at the TV set in front of her sleeping dad. She stares in the white snow, trying to see beyond the color dots. Caro Anne opens her mouth until we are certain she is going to SCREAM. Then

dialogues.speaker: CAROL ANNE
dialogues.text: Hello! Hell-ooo! What do you want Hello! who are you! Hell-ooooo!

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN FREELING
dialogues.text: His eyes open.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Diane starts and sits up quickly.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL ANNE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Who are you!! Hey! INT. DANA’S BEDROOM - NIGHT 7 She is already swinging her legs out of bed and moving in the hallway.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL ANNE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: I can’t hear you! INT. CHILDREN’S BEDROOM - NIGHT 8 Robbie looks over to see Carol Anne’s bed empty.

dialogues.speaker: NIGHT 9
dialogues.text: The entire family gathers and watches their youngest chil yelling through the static at 2:35 in the morning.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL ANNE
dialogues.text: What do you look like! Hello! Can I see you?  10

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anyone outside of Manhattan is familiar with this setting Sunday in suburbia. A neighbor mows his lawn, another was his car, and a group of kids play soccer in the street. T middle America World War II bought and paid for.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then; an irregular glitch to this setting. A man, JEFF SH is running as furiously as his jelly-bowl paunch will all In his arms, a large brown shopping bag. Barely avoiding collision with the paper boy, he cuts across the lawn, jiggling the lettering. He crashes into the front door, finding it locked. He turns and runs around back, just as Steve opens the front door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shaw blasts past Dana, dressed in a terrycloth robe. She eating potato salad right out of the bowl in front of the refrigerator.

dialogues.speaker: DANA
dialogues.text: Jesus H. Christ!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shaw almost loses his footing turning into this room. His breath exploding in wheezing puffs. He falls into a chair next to Steve Freeling and FIVE OTHER MALE NEIGHBORS who into the brown shopping bag, surfacing with Michelob Lite

dialogues.speaker: SHAW
dialogues.text: What’d I miss!?

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: Haden fumbled!

dialogues.speaker: ARNIE
dialogues.text: Sacked! !

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Oakland’s bringing out Bahr.

dialogues.speaker: SHAW
dialogues.text: Three more! Jesus! I was ahead on points, now I’m pushing.  13 14 15

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: Shhhhhhhh! ! INT. CHILDREN’S BEDROOM - DAY 13 Diane is straightening things in here when she notices something that causes her to sadly catch her breath. She walks forward to the bird cage slowly letting it out. Car Anne’s yellow canary is feet up on the bottom of the cage

dialogues.speaker: DIANE
dialogues.text: Oh Tweety, couldn’t you wait for a school day? EXT. FREELING’S BACK YARD - DAY 14 Robbie is next to a tall, misshapen oak tree that has gro bent forward, a little too close to the house. Robbie is marching in circles around the tree, acting brave. He sta to climb.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Sunday FOOTBALL CROWD is on its feet. Haden has the b again and the pass is a “bomb”.

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: Look at that fuckin’ Dennard run.

dialogues.speaker: SHAW
dialogues.text: Lester Hayes. Fuckin’ Hayes is there!! He’s there! He’s... The channel changes all by itself to Mister Rogers.

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: (yelling at the wall) Tuthill--! You asshole!

dialogues.speaker: ARNIE
dialogues.text: Turn it back! Christ!

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: Sorry guys. When my neighbor uses his remote... he’s on my same frequency. Steve turns it back to football. A second later, “Mr. Rodgers” is singing. Steve walks over to the wall, and po his remote control and fires!  16 17 18 19 From the other side of the wall comes a muffled ROAR.. Th voice of BEN TUTHILL.

dialogues.speaker: TUTHILL, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Don’t start, Freeling!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steve opens the sliding glass door and yells over the fen Tuthill, a robust man in a tank top and sunglasses, yells his window, the remote control brandished in Steve’s direction.

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: We got a game going on over here!

dialogues.speaker: TUTHILL
dialogues.text: The kids wanna watch Mr. Rodgers!

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: I don’t care what you’re watching, as long as you show a little mercy with that thing!

dialogues.speaker: TUTHILL
dialogues.text: (closing his window hard) Move your set!

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: Move yours! Tuthill clicks at Steve through his window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steve’s channels change and the gathering SCREAMS again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steve fires his remote at the Tuthills and a muffled “goddammit!” is heard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Diane has Tweety by his little claw feet at arms length. a sour grimace she moves into the bathroom and raises the toilet seat, aims Tweety and... Carol Anne steps into the doorway catching her Mom red-handed.  20

dialogues.speaker: CAROL ANNE
dialogues.text: Tweety--!!

dialogues.speaker: DIANE
dialogues.text: (barely audible) Oh shit. EXT. FREELING’S BACK YARD - DAY 20 With his own bedroom window facing him, Robbie climbs amo the twisted branches, then looks at the neighborhood and sky beyond.

dialogues.speaker: SKY
dialogues.text: Storm clouds are gathering in the distance.

dialogues.speaker: CIGAR BOX
dialogues.text: Diane places little Tweety into the cigar box. She starts close the lid.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL ANNE
dialogues.text: Tweety doesn’t like that smell.

dialogues.speaker: DIANE
dialogues.text: Sweetheart, Tweety can’t smell a thing.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL ANNE
dialogues.text: (giving orders) Put a flower with him. Diane smiles at this thought and takes a red rose from th vase on the windowsill. Carol Anne pulls into her pocket takes out some red licorice. She bites off the end, spits out into her hand and places the wet piece inside the cig box.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL ANNE
dialogues.text: For when he’s hungry. She places a Polaroid snapshot of herself and Robbie.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL ANNE
dialogues.text: For when he’s lonely. She covers him with a napkin.  22

dialogues.speaker: CAROL ANNE
dialogues.text: For when it’s nighttime. Carol Anne starts to cry as she closes the lid. Diane loo on. She really loves this kid. EXT. FREELING’S BACK YARD - DAY 22 Diane has dug a hole in the dirt. Robbie and Dana watch a Carol Anne places the cigar box into the earth. Dana is eating celery and Diane throws her a “you’re chewing too loud” look. Robbie, from up in the tree, watches fascinat as Diane and Carol Anne refill the hole. In the backgroun the football game is winding up with loud interludes betw the time-outs of the final quarter

dialogues.speaker: CAROL ANNE
dialogues.text: Now I lay me down to sleep, I pray the Lord my soul to keep...

dialogues.speaker: DANA
dialogues.text: (rolls her eyes) Brother...

dialogues.speaker: DIANE
dialogues.text: (to Dana) Stifle it!

dialogues.speaker: CAROL ANNE
dialogues.text: If I should die before I wake...

dialogues.speaker: DANA
dialogues.text: (a defiant whisper) It did.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL ANNE
dialogues.text: I pray the Lord my soul to take.

dialogues.speaker: DIANE
dialogues.text: That was lovely, honey.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: (staring at the freshly dug earth, calls down from the tree) Mom, when it rots can we dig it up and see the bones?

dialogues.speaker: DIANE
dialogues.text: Robbie! !  23

dialogues.speaker: CAROL ANNE
dialogues.text: (brightening-- a new topic) Can I get a goldfish now?! INT. CHILDREN’S BEDROOM - NIGHT 23

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carol Anne stares wondrously as two brand new goldfish ni Hertz Mountain from the surface. Robbie sits on his bed i his PJ's reading a Popeye comic. Distant THUNDER can be h as Robbie looks over at his window. ROBBIE’S POV A weak flash of lightning outlines the tree he was playin earlier. It is not merely the overactive imagination of a nine-year-old that makes this tree scary to us. The twist branches that seem to suggest arms and the split trunk th appears to suggest horns is all too real even at first glance.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: He doesn’t want to look. He doesn’t want to scare himself But he does.

dialogues.speaker: DIANE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Honey, you’re overfeeding them.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL ANNE
dialogues.text: Tweety-two and Tweety-three wants seconds.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: Mom, there’s a big storm headed this way.

dialogues.speaker: DIANE
dialogues.text: You’11 be asleep by the time it gets here... if you hurry. Lights out! The kids dive for the covers. Diane turns out the light. room is overwhelmed by darkness. Carol Anne speaks up fir  24

dialogues.speaker: CAROL ANNE
dialogues.text: (rapidly) Closet light! Closet light

dialogues.speaker: DIANE
dialogues.text: My fault. My fault. Diane turns on the light in their closet and cracks open door. Carol Anne relaxes and waves good-night to her fish Robbie looks over at the rocking chair by the bureau. Sit straight up is clown doll. It is almost the size of Robbi Its stare is devilish and its smile is just a little too broad for comedy. Robbie gets up and without looking at the doll, throws a plaid shirt over its head. He climbs back into bed, outli by a blue flash from the window.

dialogues.speaker: DUTCH MASTER CIGAR BOX
dialogues.text: Two hands lift it from the shadows and into the light. Th lid starts to open and just as we expect to see Tweety-on see the “stash” instead. Steve removes a lid of grass and some zigzag papers and starts to roll a joint. On the TV an old MGM movie. Diane is reading Carl Jung’s MAN AND HIS SYMBOLS. Steve p up a brochure on pool equipment and diving boards.

dialogues.speaker: DIANE
dialogues.text: (taking a hit) Sleepwalking. Sleepwalking. Nocturnal Somnambulism. * I’11 betcha it’s genetic. Carol Anne all last week and then last night. Me when I was ten. I once walked four blocks and fell asleep in the back seat of this man’s car. He went all the way to work before discovering me. God. I started screaming... people ran over. The police came. They took the guy downtown. My father had me examined for bruises hickeys, I don’t know. Oh shit, Steven! If we dig the pool and Carol Anne falls in before there’s any water... Steven... are you listening?  10. Steven takes the joint back from Diane and pulls it down halfway in one breath -- holding the hit

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: (he talks like Dennis Hopper ) Ever go off a three meter board?

dialogues.speaker: DIANE
dialogues.text: What’s three meters?

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: About ten feet.

dialogues.speaker: DIANE
dialogues.text: Honey, why don’t we just build the pool closer to the house and let he kids jump off the roof? ct

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: See, it’s like an air pocket. From three meters you’re free-falling. You can maybe squeeze in a half- gainer, jackknife into a swan twist back, tuck, splash.

dialogues.speaker: DIANE
dialogues.text: Splat!!

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: Spashhh.

dialogues.speaker: DIANE
dialogues.text: Splurg.

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: Honey, we can afford it.

dialogues.speaker: DIANE
dialogues.text: We don’t really need it.

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: It’s great for business. We build the first house. We install the first pool. Look around us. By summer (in bass baritone) “the hills are alive with the smell of chlorine”.

dialogues.speaker: DIANE
dialogues.text: Yeah and, our pool will be alive with a thousand guests.  25 11.

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: I’m the wind and you’re the feather!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: INT. CHILDREN’S BEDROOM - NIGHT 25 Steven flops Robbie onto his pillow just as a flash light the room and the tree outside the window. Carol Anne lies awake, watching.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: I don’t like the tree, Dad.

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: It’s an old tree. It was here for a long time. Long before my company built this neighborhood.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: I don’t like its arms. It knows I live here, doesn’t it?

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: (not aware this scares Robbie) It knows everything about us. That’s why I built our home next to it. So it could protect you and Carol Anne, Dana, your mom and me. It’s a wise old tree.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: It looks at me. It knows I live here. Robbie is visibly frightened now and Steven realizes he’s scared him. Just then a tremor of thunder rolls through t bedroom and Robbie snuggles up to his dad.

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: Storm’s gonna miss us.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: How do you know?

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: Because I can count. Then more thunder. Robbie flinches, but tries to be brave  26 12.

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: After you see the lightning, count until you hear the thunder. If you can count higher each time, that means the storm is moving away from you. A flash of lightning is seen.

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: Now count with me.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE/STEVEN/CAROL ANNE
dialogues.text: One, two, three... Thunder is HEARD.

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: Next time you’ll be able to count to four or more. You try it, okay?

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: Okay. Steven exits leaving the door open. Lightning occurs. Ste waits by the partially open door and listens as Robbie counts.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: (very worried) One... two... three... four... five... Distant thunder is HEARD. Robbie is more relieved. INT. HALLWAY OUTSIDE DANA’S BEDROOM - NIGHT 26 He feels real good about himself. He KNOCKS on Dana’s doo Music is HEARD. The door opens.

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: Goodnight, Dana.

dialogues.speaker: DANA
dialogues.text: Uh, goodnight, Dad. (a beat, then)

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: Get off the phone, Dana.  27 28

dialogues.speaker: DANA
dialogues.text: (caught ) Okay, Dad. INT. CHILDREN’S BEDROOM - NIGHT 27 Robbie looks out the window. The tree stands there in the wind. Another flash of lightning, Robbie controls his fea and concentrates.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: One, two... CRACK! BOOM! An explosive jolt of thunder rocks the house The closet light goes out as the tree outside the window suddenly bends forward as if looking in. Robbie sits bolt upright. Carol Anne wakes up SCREAMING.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carol Anne and Robbie are asleep next to Diane and Steve. TV has been left on and the National Anthem starts to pla

dialogues.speaker: FAMILY
dialogues.text: Various positions, asleep.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The pre-recorded voice of the station manager signs off. beat... Transmission ceases and the soft roar of dead air fills the room as the static white snow colors the walls making shadows flicker and warp. It is only now that we first hear it. A SOUND intermingli with the TV hiss, like a bad connection from far, far awa whisper. Not one, but hundreds of them. They say nothing. It’s a chorus, tonal and inviting.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL ANNE 28-B
dialogues.text: She turns on her side. And her eyes open surreally. Ever slowly, she turns her head fully facing the TV. Carol Ann smiles. A smile much too sophisticated for a five-years-o child.

dialogues.speaker: TV SCREEN 28-C
dialogues.text: The snow mixes with new imagery. Forms. Vague but luminou Always mingling. Impressionistic. Never hard-lined.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL ANNE
dialogues.text: (whispering) Come out... come out... The picture tube starts to SNAP! Little flashes momentari blind Carol Anne. She blinks and tries to see deeper. SNA CRACK! It’s as if flashbulbs were being emitted. Steven a Diane turn fitfully but remain asleep. FLASH! POP! Robbie close to waking.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL ANNE 28-D
dialogues.text: Smiling, on her knees now... she reaches out toward the T screen when... SOMETHING REACHES BACK. A Substance. A for like a wispy, smoky tentacle twists forward, EXTENDING FR THE PICTURE TUBE and snaking into the Freeling bedroom. Transparent and cold, it gives birth to itself, builds up its own energy, growing brighter as it seems to hover abo Carol Anne, then tower over the family asleep in the king sized bed.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL ANNE 28-E
dialogues.text: She must bend her neck to look all the way up at the ceil where this cyclonic shape waltzes... studying.. at the ro then Carol Anne... AN EXPLOSION from the TV set. The brightest flash yet experienced. A force that expels the intruder from the se and into the room. Catapulting it past the family and int the wall RIGHT OVER THE BED, where it leaves a dark penci dot stain. The entire room shakes and the family is awake panicked. The window cracks, the curtain rod slips. Books and memen fall from the open hutch. The medicine cabinet opens and prescription medicine splatters on the tiled floor. The r lights flare then die. Every picture topples from the wal Just as quickly as it began, the episode ceases. A HUSH 2 descends. Everyone looks at Carol Anne. Carol Anne looks everyone... then intones, almost matter-of-factly.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL ANNE
dialogues.text: They’re here.  29 30 15. EXT. FREELING’S BACK YARD - DAY 29

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A work glove shifts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A steel-toed workboot slowly withdraws.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lurch forward, dripping sod and wet grass. The shovel of the bulldozer touches the earth and scrapes deep swathe. CAMERA MOVES CLOSER as the cigar box coffin is cruelly exhumed in the ever-growing tidal wave of back yard turf.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steve is on the phone, nervously smoking a cigarette as t bulldozer can be seen out the window, digging the new poo Diane is serving waffles around the breakfast table. E. B sits at Robbie’s feet, watching the waffles hopefully. On Carol Anne seems to have an appetite.

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: (on the phone) I’m not kidding, Jeff. How could anyone sleep through a six-point- five. Yes, damage. Stuff’s in pieces all over our bedroom.

dialogues.speaker: DIANE
dialogues.text: (quietly to Carol Anne) Chew each bite ten times. Carol Anne exaggerates her chewing; smiling with her mout full.

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: I know that... we’ve had the radio on and there’s nothing about it. (after a beat) After the Sylmar quake it was two years before real estate was on the rise.  16. Diane is gently coaxing some information out of Carol Ann who mostly has her mouth full of waffles and blueberries.

dialogues.speaker: DIANE
dialogues.text: When you said, “They’re here” last night.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL ANNE
dialogues.text: Can I take my goldfish to school?

dialogues.speaker: DANA
dialogues.text: Maybe the fault line runs just under our house. Wouldn’t that be a scream?

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: The ceiling got crumbs all over my bed.

dialogues.speaker: DIANE
dialogues.text: (to Carol Anne) Sweetheart. Do you remember last night? Do you remember when you woke up and said, “They’re here?”

dialogues.speaker: CAROL ANNE
dialogues.text: Uh huh.

dialogues.speaker: DIANE
dialogues.text: Who did you mean? Who’s here?

dialogues.speaker: CAROL ANNE
dialogues.text: (mouth full) The TV people.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: She’s stoned.

dialogues.speaker: DANA
dialogues.text: What do you know about it?

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: More’n you. Ask Dad. Robbie picks up his milk to take a sip when the bottom of glass drops out, the milk splashing back onto Robbie’s ce bowl, overflowing cereal all over the table and onto Dana blouse in a burst, perhaps slightly strong for the small amount of spilled milk

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: (throwing up his hands) It’s not my mess.

dialogues.speaker: DANA
dialogues.text: (jumps up from the table) Thanks a lot, jerko - I’ve got class in twenty minutes.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: Mom.

dialogues.speaker: DIANE
dialogues.text: Gimme that thing before you cut yourself. Carol Anne has a big dripping splash of milk running down forehead. Oblivious to this she just keeps eating, goes o to the kitchen TV... turns it on to the “Today Show”, the switches to an “in between” channel and watches the snow.

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: I’m outta here! See ya early.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: (imitating Dad) I’m outta here!

dialogues.speaker: DIANE
dialogues.text: (pushing him back) You I can handle.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: I got school!!

dialogues.speaker: DIANE
dialogues.text: Breakfast first.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: (casually) All right, I’1l just flunk. Robbie shrugs, reaches for his spoon to resume eating and notices something unusual. The spoon is bent. He looks ar the table. Every spoon is bent. Shrugging it off, Robbie lifts his cereal bowl and drinks right out of it, two tin trails dripping off his chin, spotting his school shirt.  31 32 33 18. EXT. FREELING’S BACK YARD - DAY 31 A big man, PUGSLEY, thirties, bald, steps out of his pool install action truck wearing combat boots, a Teamster T- shirt, mirrored sunglasses and a baseball cap turned arou backwards on his head. He motions to the bulldozer driver “take a gander”. Dana grabs her bike and rides off. The workmen pause to stare at her. Pugsley and the dozer driv share a salacious grin and the dozer driver pops his clut rapidly, the dozer lurching suggestively several times.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Diane has witnessed this sloppy display through the open door. Choosing to pass over it, she turns toward the kitc table to clean up. E. BUZZ, the dog, is sitting on a pull out chair eating from everyone’s plates. Diane sighs and shoos E. Buzz away.

dialogues.speaker: DIANE
dialogues.text: When you leave the table, Carol Anne... Robbie, you push your chairs in. Carol Anne is trying to fine-tune the snow on television.

dialogues.speaker: DIANE
dialogues.text: Aw, honey you’re going to ruin your eyes. This is not good for you. She turns the set to another channel where a WAR MOVIE is showing. Soldiers blowing up and screaming.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Diane is cleaning up. Broken glass surrounds her. She cup her left hand and picks narrow shards out of the shag whe the GROWLING begins. Diane turns and sees... DIANE’S POV E. BUZZ is growling at the wall. Looking up at something don’t see. Diane sidesteps the broken vases to follow E. Buzz’s eyeline right up the wall and onto the stain.

dialogues.speaker: DIANE
dialogues.text: She cocks her head curiously.

It has grown since this morning. Like a Rorschach pattern Diane tries to rub it out with a pillowcase. She slips in the bathroom and wets one corner, then returns when... Diane stops. Carefully, she watches E. Buzz, who has ceas growling.

dialogues.speaker: DIANE AND E. BUZZ
dialogues.text: Never removing his spaniel eyes from the wall, E. Buzz’ t starts wagging. He backs a scoot away from the wall and executes and obedient “roll-over”. Diane herself retreats

dialogues.speaker: DIANE
dialogues.text: (gently) C’mere, E. Buzz. E. Buzz turns, but his mind is not on Diane. He runs out the room between Diane’s legs immediately returning with chew-ball. E. Buzz sidles up to the wall and sets his che ball down, “speaks” and executes a double roll-over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Diane enters, sees Pugsley drinking a cup of coffee from of her China cups.

dialogues.speaker: DIANE
dialogues.text: (at doorway, to Pugsley) Okay, Bluto! Gimme my cup.

dialogues.speaker: PUGSLEY
dialogues.text: Gee, Mrs. Freeling you make great coffee. Good for a second cup. Pugsley breaks out laughing. Diane grabs the cup out of h hands and drops the blinds in his face.

dialogues.speaker: KITCHEN TABLE 34-A
dialogues.text: Diane turns to find all the chairs are withdrawn from the intended places. She looks for Carol Anne then jumps half out of her skin. Carol Anne is right behind her, tapping her on the side.

dialogues.speaker: DIANE
dialogues.text: Jesus, don’t do that. You wanna see your mommy lying in a cigar box covered in licorice?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 35 20. Carol Anne shakes her head... slowly.

dialogues.speaker: DIANE
dialogues.text: (pointing to chairs) Did you do that? Carol Anne shakes her head slowly. Diane replaces the chairs in their proper places and retu to the sink. She opens the cupboard under the sink, and brings out a bottle of 409. She stands and turns around..

dialogues.speaker: FACING HER IS THE KITCHEN TABLE 34-B
dialogues.text: The chairs are stacked one atop the other, reaching all t way up to the ceiling. Diane jams her fist into her mouth press back the natural reaction. Carol Anne stands below smiling up at the pyramid.

dialogues.speaker: DIANE
dialogues.text: (a whisper to Carol Anne) The TV people?

dialogues.speaker: CAROL ANNE
dialogues.text: Up there.

dialogues.speaker: DIANE
dialogues.text: (barely audible) Do you see them?

dialogues.speaker: CAROL ANNE
dialogues.text: No... do you?

dialogues.speaker: DIANE
dialogues.text: Uh uh.

dialogues.speaker: IDENTICAL KITCHEN
dialogues.text: In a disconcerting jump, all of the furniture, Carol Anne Diane disappear. The basic structure of the kitchen remai exactly the same for this is a model home somewhere in Cu Verde Estates. Steve Freeling walks into the empty setting with a family prospective buyers. Only the wallpaper is different from Freeling residence.  21.

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: This, then, is our latest development. We call it phase four

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN BUYER
dialogues.text: Where is your home, Mr. Freeling?

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: We were the first family to set up housekeeping in Cuesta Verde Estates.

dialogues.speaker: HUSBAND
dialogues.text: (helping) Phase one!

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: That’s right. Actually you passed through my neighborhood to get here.

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN BUYER
dialogues.text: The area with that “lived in” look.

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: In a month you won’t be able to distinguish phase four from phase one from phase... well, around here grass grows greener on every side.

dialogues.speaker: HUSBAND
dialogues.text: Yeah... I can’t tell one house from the other.

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: Our construction standards are very liberal. Matter of fact, a neighbor of mine put a jacuzzi in his bedroom, with a running aqueduct connecting it to the wading pool outside which he built half in half out of his living room. That home was featured in last month’s issue of Town and Country.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 37 38 22. Sparse lightning over the mountains as the storm clouds b to roll in. The neighborhood is quiet. Warm window light spill is out across the well manicured lawns. You can alm smell two hundred dinners in all of the ovens of Cuesta Verde. EXT. STREET/FREELING’S HOUSE - DUSK 37 Steve Freeling’s Oldsmobile station wagon turns down the block heading home.

dialogues.speaker: FREEWAY DRIVEWAY
dialogues.text: Three empty trashcans block the drive... Steve groans as parks half on, half off the curb, climbs out, and starts removing obstacles when from nowhere Diane is there, literally pulling toward the house.

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: Hey babe. Guess who just bought L-J 237...

dialogues.speaker: DIANE
dialogues.text: Just c’mere! Hurry!

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: Wait a sec., I’m parked in the street.

dialogues.speaker: DIANE
dialogues.text: Leave it. Quick, before it stops again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We have never seen Diane focused and again so frazzled. H words are coming in spurts. She must constantly catch her breath. The thrill in her voice is backed up against an oppressive fear.

dialogues.speaker: DIANE
dialogues.text: Okay, okay... look. Okay. Listen. I’ve kept Dana and Robbie out of this, but Carol Anne was with me when it started so I cut her in, but Dana would blab and Robbie’d be up for three weeks sleeping on your side of the bed.  23.

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: Diane, put the breaks on will ya. Just sit down a sec.

dialogues.speaker: DIANE
dialogues.text: No, goddammit, you sit down! I mean... stand right there. And just... just have an open mind. Reach back into our past when I used to know you with one and use it for the next coupla minutes. Carol Anne suddenly appears from around the corner lookin exhausted and cranky. In her hand is a San Diego Charger football helmet.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL ANNE
dialogues.text: Mommy didn’t cook any dinner.

dialogues.speaker: DIANE
dialogues.text: (loud) We’ll go to Pizza Hut, all right?

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Looking around he sees chalk marks all over the kitchen floor. Arrows and squares and numbers in two colors. Diane’s breathing quickens as she steadies herself. Skipp to the kitchen table she takes one of the colonial countr chairs from the breakfast table and scrapes it along the floor to the center of the room where four circles have b described in chalk. Diane places each leg in one of the proscribed circles and looks up at Steve.

dialogues.speaker: DIANE
dialogues.text: (last words) Okay... okay now, watch!! Watch!! She removes her hands from the back of the chair and step aside. Steve watches Diane as much as the chair. He start step forward when Diane throws both of her hands out to s him.

dialogues.speaker: DIANE
dialogues.text: Look! The chair begins to tremble. It virtually jitterbugs in place... then begins to move forward picking up speed unt it traverses the entire length of the kitchen ending up r in front of Steve’s bullfrog eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yawning.

dialogues.speaker: DIANE
dialogues.text: With hysterical victory in her eyes.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Looking for wires. He kneels and feels the chair legs, th immediately looks to Diane for the answer.

dialogues.speaker: DIANE
dialogues.text: It’s okay. It’s okay. Look! (to Carol Anne) Sweetheart, show Daddy.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL ANNE
dialogues.text: (angry now) I’m hungry.

dialogues.speaker: DIANE
dialogues.text: Don’t argue! ! Carol Anne shrugs and puts on the football helmet. Diane over to Steve’s side and pushes the chair out of the way. Carol Anne sits on the floor in a circle with her name on in yellow chalk.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Starts to run for her protectively. Diane restrains him.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL ANNE
dialogues.text: She starts to tremble as if on a funhouse ride. Her littl body begins to move forward, faster, and all the way acro the kitchen floor right into Diane’s arms.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL ANNE
dialogues.text: (rubbing her fanny) That burned!

dialogues.speaker: DIANE
dialogues.text: Sorry, baby, floor needed more wax.

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: What the fuck!!

dialogues.speaker: DIANE
dialogues.text: You try!

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: What???  25.

dialogues.speaker: DIANE
dialogues.text: You can’t believe the feeling.

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: What’s the gag? There a magnet back there? He looks behind the door in the dining room. Nothing. Ste just stands for a long moment in hapless silence, then...

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: I hate Pizza Hut! Where’s supper? I don’t understand, Diane. What the hell’s going on around here? Steve sidesteps the chalk marks, removing himself from th active area.

dialogues.speaker: DIANE
dialogues.text: I figured I’d never explain it to you. So I showed you instead, but don’t ask me how or what. Just help me figure out what to do.

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: You mean there’s no gimmick?

dialogues.speaker: DIANE
dialogues.text: Not from inside the house. Maybe Tuthill got himself a super remote from the Radio Shack. Carol Anne adjusts her helmet and sits inside her launch circle. Diane and Steve are having the discussion across room and aren’t aware of her.

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: Maybe the shake-up and this thing... relate.

dialogues.speaker: DIANE
dialogues.text: No shit.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL ANNE
dialogues.text: Daddy, look at me!! They turn but it’s too late. Carol Anne shoots across the room faster than before, and with no one to catch her.

dialogues.speaker: KITCHEN WALL
dialogues.text: At a sickening speed her helmet smashes into the wall. Di SCREAMS. Steve runs over  39 40 41 42 26. An eight-inch hole in the wall and the cracked plastic on helmet testify to the force of impact. Carol Anne is daze but unhurt.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL ANNE
dialogues.text: You promised pizza.

dialogues.speaker: OMITTED 41
dialogues.text: EXT. BEN TUTHILL’S FRONT PORCH - LIGHT 42 The front door opens and Tuthill steps into the bug light obvious strain in this conversation. The motives various, the feelings mutual. About a thousan mosquitos chow down on the Freelings while they talk.

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: Hi, Ben.

dialogues.speaker: DIANE
dialogues.text: Mr. Tuthill.

dialogues.speaker: TUTHILL
dialogues.text: Tv’s off in here. If your set’s acting up again...

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: (laughing nervously) No, no, uh-uh. Nothing like that. We were wondering... although this is going to sound strange coming from me.

dialogues.speaker: TUTHILL
dialogues.text: I doubt it.

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: (swatting the mosquitos) These mosquitos... Jesus.

dialogues.speaker: TUTHILL
dialogues.text: (so nonchalantly) They never bothered me. I never been bitten by one.  27. TUTHILL(cont'd) Far as I know, no member of my family’s effected by ‘em. (grabs his fourteen-years- old kid) Mosquito ever suck on you, son?

dialogues.speaker: KID
dialogues.text: Heck, I don’t know, Dad. Meanwhile Diane and Steve are being massacred.

dialogues.speaker: TUTHILL
dialogues.text: He don’t know. Suddenly, there is a crash from somewhere inside the Tuth home. Tuthill glances causally over his shoulder, turns b to Diane and removes a wet piece of cigar tobacco from th tip of his tongue.

dialogues.speaker: DIANE
dialogues.text: Mr. Tuthill, what my husband was wondering...

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: (breaking in) Yes. You see, Ben, something funny in our house... next door. Something...

dialogues.speaker: DIANE
dialogues.text: You been having any disturbances lately?

dialogues.speaker: TUTHILL
dialogues.text: (suspiciously) What sort of disturbances?

dialogues.speaker: DIANE
dialogues.text: (trying to be casual) Oh, dishes or furniture moving -- around by themselves?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Diane is applying calamine lotion to Steve’s neck and wri

dialogues.speaker: DIANE
dialogues.text: I had to say something. I was losing a pint of blood every few seconds.  44 28.

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: I think we should keep this thing in the family. In the morning I’1l call someone in.

dialogues.speaker: DIANE
dialogues.text: Who for instance? I’ve already looked in the yellow pages. Furniture movers we got. Strange Phenomenon... there’s no listing.

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: Okay. I have a plan. I have a plan. Something’s occurring here that we can’t explain. If Carol Anne wasn’t wearing that helmet...

dialogues.speaker: DIANE
dialogues.text: Okay, stop it.

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: What if she wasn’t? Jesus, Diane. we’d be at County Emergency and not getting ready for bed.

dialogues.speaker: DIANE
dialogues.text: Okay already!

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: Right. Okay. Let’s wake the kids. No big deal! Let’s wake them, spend tonight at the Travel Lodge in Broxton. And come back tomorrow with experts! Experts who can tell us what it is that’s happening and if it’s safe to go home.

dialogues.speaker: DIANE
dialogues.text: Now you’re scaring me. Don’t try and scare me, Steve. INT. CHILDREN’S BEDROOM - NIGHT 44 Robbie is wide awake. He is staring out the window from u the covers. There is a flash of lightning. Robbie begins nervously counting.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: One... two... three... four... five...  46 29. The SOUND of rolling thunder. Robbie tenses and watches t tree.

dialogues.speaker: WINDOW
dialogues.text: A wind rustles the gnarled branches. The sky is a rolling mass of gray and black. A second flash of lightning and Robbie whispers to himsel

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: One... two... three... CRACKLE! RUMBLE! The window pane vibrates as the shock wa from the thunder bears down and the wind begins to dance the tree.

dialogues.speaker: DIANE
dialogues.text: (getting her back up) I’m the one who lived with this freaky thing all day. And nothing bad happened. It’s like another side of nature. A side you and I are not qualified to comprehend. When you overreact like this it makes what happened much too important.

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: Nobody goes into the kitchen until we know what’s happening.

dialogues.speaker: DIANE
dialogues.text: (looking through the stash box) We’re out of papers. INT. CHILDREN’S BEDROOM - NIGHT 46 Robbie is watching the tree. Carol Anne is asleep but she tossing and moaning like the wind outside the window. Another FLASH OF LIGHTNING. Robbie pulls the covers up ov his nose and mouth. His little breath pushing the fabric and down as he counts.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: One... two...

KA-BOOM! The room vibrates and Robbie takes his eyes off window for just a moment, looking at the open bedroom doo and the light down the hall from his parent’s room. He co be out of bed and there in six seconds if he hurried.

dialogues.speaker: ON TOP OF IT.
dialogues.text: Robbie snaps a look at the window just in time to see it happen. ROBBIE’S POV 46-A A hurricane BLAST of wind hits the monster oak. The two branches resembling arms fold forward aiming at the windo The disfigured crown with the horns and knotty eyes bends back before tipping forward. The finger-twigs at the end of the arms reach out hungril

dialogues.speaker: THE WINDOW 46-B
dialogues.text: THE ENTIRE TREE CRASHES THROUGH ROBBIE’S WINDOW. A FURNACE OF LIGHTNING accents the assault. Robbie starts SCREAMING. The finger-twigs wrap around him like skeleton hands and lift him right out of bed. Carol Anne sits up and SCREAMS for Diane. The tree seems to be exhaling. Its breath enveloping Robb in a phantom haze. The arms begin to retract pulling Robb toward the mouth and eyes.

dialogues.speaker: ON THE DOOR 46-C
dialogues.text: Just then, Steve and Diane appear in the doorway. Diane SCREAMS as... The tree pulls Robbie right out the window and into an ei mile-per-hour night. The ROAR of wind is almost unbearabl drowning Robbie’s SCREAMS and those of his parents and Da who suddenly appears in the doorway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carol Anne is suddenly forgotten as Dana, Diane and Steve hurl themselves downstairs and through the kitchen, only find the door blocked by several large branches.

dialogues.speaker: 46-F
dialogues.text: 47 48 49 31. They scramble back through the kitchen, out the sliding g door and into the raging storm. INT. CHILDREN’S BEDROOM - ANGLE - CAROL ANNE 46-E The force from the shattered window shoves Carol Anne aga the headboard of her bed where she hugs her clown doll wi a a 11 her might, its broad smile suddenly disconcerting as i ppears to be looking toward the closet in her room.

dialogues.speaker: NGLE
dialogues.text: pace in this five-year-old’s tiny, tiny world. Carol Anne Al The closet door opens revealing the most feared and dread s looks where her doll is looking and SCREAMS horribly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The storm lashes the tree. The tree lashes Robbie. RAIN a WIND and CONDENSATION make it difficult to see everything Sixty branches form a briar prison that starts to tear an strangle. Steve races outside. A WALL of WIND makes his r SLOW MOTION. INT. CHILDREN’S BEDROOM 48

dialogues.speaker: THE CLOSET
dialogues.text: The light inside grows to a supernatural intensity and a SOUND unlike anything anyone would ever want to hear blas through the velocity of the storm. It is the closet sucki the bedroom into its murderous glare. Anything not tied d is swallowed. Carol Anne grabs her covers, and SCREAMS. N SOUND comes out. She is lifted completely off the bed by the suction. Only death-grip on the sheets keeps her away. Unbelievably, he clown doll is not affected by the vacuum pull. It just si on the floor where Carol Anne dropped it and stares up at her, smiling.

dialogues.speaker: TREE
dialogues.text: Steve reaches the twisting trunk and starts to climb. Dia SCREAMING from the patio is lost in the storm.  50 52 53 54 32. Steve reaches Robbie and the fight is defined only by the flare of stroboscopic lightning. Every time it appears as though Robbie will be freed, branches envelop him and win him tighter. INT. CHILDREN’S BEDROOM - NIGHT 50 CLOSE - CAROL ANNE’S TINY HANDS The sheets start to peel back. The closet swallows toys a posters of Darth Vader and R2D2, then sucks harder, the N something like a colossal straw pulling at the last drop a deep, deep well. Only now does the bed give way, flippi into the air and flying across the room, slamming Carol A inside and blocking the opening with its frame and spring

dialogues.speaker: TREE
dialogues.text: Steve tears at the branches, trying to free Robbie. A cri fluid pumps thick from the branches that Steve destroys. suddenly as it began, the final burst of wind passes the like the caboose at the end of a runaway train. He frees son and they topple out of the tree. Robbie throws his ar around his Dad and the two hold on for their lives, gaspi hugging, choking on the rain and sap. The tree is uproote before them and disappears into the storm.

dialogues.speaker: OMITTED 52
dialogues.text: EXT. FREELING’S BACK YARD - NIGHT 53 Steve and Robbie lie on the ground. Both are numb and buzzing. Diane runs over and hugs them. Then Dana looks i the sky and points to the horizon.

dialogues.speaker: DANA
dialogues.text: Look, Mom... Dad!!! Diane and Steve look off into the sky miles away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A funnel cloud is moving away from Cuesta Verde Estates breaking up as it hits the outlying hills.  55 56 57 33. EXT. FREELING’S BACK YARD - NIGHT 55

dialogues.speaker: DANA
dialogues.text: A night twister!

dialogues.speaker: DIANE
dialogues.text: It must of just skimmed us. There wouldn’t be a house standing if...

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Carol Anne!!

dialogues.speaker: DANA
dialogues.text: Upstairs?

dialogues.speaker: DIANE
dialogues.text: (looking at the shattered upstairs window) My God! Everyone runs to the house. INT. UPSTAIRS HALL TO CHILDREN’S BEDROOM - NIGHT 56 Steve and Diane are first into the room. Their expression say it all. INT. CHILDREN’S BEDROOM - NIGHT 57

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With the exception of the two beds blocking the closet, Robbie and Carol Anne’s room is stripped clean. Diane let out a muffled shriek and throws herself against the barricade, pulling back mattresses, boxsprings and blanke Steve joins her and together they work side by side, pant crying and calling for Carol Anne.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: Still in a state of complete dislocation, Robbie walks ba into his bedroom and looks at the window. The tree is the no longer. E. Buzz, the dog, joins Robbie, whimpering at feet.

dialogues.speaker: THE CLOSET
dialogues.text: 58 34. Over Diane, SCREAMING out Carol Anne’s name, Steve does t muscle work, pulling off end tables, Lone Ranger lamps, c of drawers, toys and stuffed animals, working his way to bottom of this innocent debris. CAMERA STARTS TO MOVE IN. Going beyond Steve to his hands work as he lifts the last layer of mayhem off Carol Anne’ favorite pink blanket. There is a folded lump beneath it. The lump doesn’t stir. Diane covers her mouth and hyperventilates as Steve gentl removes the fuzzy blanket and... IT IS THE CLOWN DOLL, SMILING UP AT THEM OUTRAGEOUSLY.

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: She’s not here!

dialogues.speaker: DIANE
dialogues.text: (turning and calling) Carol Anne! Dana goes to the shattered window and calls out.

dialogues.speaker: DANA
dialogues.text: I’1l check the kitchen!

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: Don’t go in there! I’1l check it. You look in your room.

dialogues.speaker: DIANE
dialogues.text: I’1l go!! Look in the bathrooms!

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: Robbie’s expression never changes as everyone pushes past on the run. He slowly walks to the closet and looks in. ROBBIE’S POV The clown.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steve swings into the room. The television set is on but local transmitter must be out. There is only static snow.

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: Carol Anne!! No answer.  59 60 61 62 35.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dana opens the door.

dialogues.speaker: DANA
dialogues.text: Carol Anne! Carol! She walks over to the shower stall and suddenly parts the curtains. There is nothing inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Diane passes the TV. Snow, but no transmission. She check the bed, the closet, the bathroom, becoming more frantic every dashed hope.

dialogues.speaker: DIANE
dialogues.text: Oh Jesus Christ Almighty. Carol Anne!

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: This is crazy. I’ve looked everywhere.

dialogues.speaker: DIANE
dialogues.text: (suddenly realizing) Oh my God. The swimming pool! Everyone breaks running. Again passing Robbie in the hall Robbie turns into his mother’s room. The SOUND OF TV STAT and blue video glow growing stronger with every step.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dana, Steve and Diane race to the edge. The rain has soft the edges and Dana’s feet slide out from under her. She starts to fall when Diane grabs her wrist, Dana simply dangles above the deep end, filled with two feet of rainw and mud. Steve slides down the steep muddy shoot from thr to nine feet and plunges his hands into the quagmire. He finds nothing.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: The blue TV light flattens Robbie’s features, accentuatin his lingering catatonia.  63

dialogues.speaker: 63-A
dialogues.text: 64 36. The TV HISS is growing steadily and Robbie starts to regi something. From the back of his eyes, awareness regains awareness that shifts to terror. Robbie opens his little mouth and produces a low MOAN that slides relentlessly to upper registers of primal release.

dialogues.speaker: DIANE
dialogues.text: She almost has Dana pulled out when the SOUND reaches her preferential instinct forces Diane to let go. Dana falls feet into her father’s arms.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Diane is already inside the house and heading down the ha

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Robbie is stationed not six inches from the nineteen-inch screen, hysterical, holding his hair in his fists. Diane grabs him up and locks her eyes to his.

dialogues.speaker: DIANE
dialogues.text: What is it?! Oh my Christ, what is it?!!! The STATIC HISS is almost unbearable. Through it all we c still make out “the voice”.

dialogues.speaker: VOICE
dialogues.text: Mommy... Diane frantically searches the room.

dialogues.speaker: DIANE
dialogues.text: Carol Anne! Where are you?! Diane puts Robbie down and runs in a wide circle looking. HISS is everywhere. E. Buzz growls at the TV.

dialogues.speaker: VOICE
dialogues.text: Mommy... Diane is hysterical now. The first time we’ve seen her lo control.  65 37.

dialogues.speaker: DIANE
dialogues.text: I’m here, baby! Oh God, baby, I’m here!

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: Walking to the TV screen again.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: Mommy. Here! Here! ! Diane turns to look. She freezes, and only the rivulets o perspiration move across her. Diane doesn’t even breathe.

dialogues.speaker: TV SET
dialogues.text: Carol Anne’s voice is heard again, buried deeply behind t horizontal blurring, the electron bombardment, the swirls snow and noise.

dialogues.speaker: VOICE
dialogues.text: I can’t see you. Mommy. Where are you?!

dialogues.speaker: DIANE
dialogues.text: Her eyes roll white, her head lulls and we FADE OUT.

dialogues.speaker: LATER
dialogues.text: INT. DR. LESH’S OFFICE - U.C. IRVINE 65 Three banks of cold fluorescent purr down from the ceilin CAMERA PANS DOWN, past rows of metal bookshelves from whi reams of notes, files and textbooks hang in no organized manner. Finally, the view STOPS on DR. MARTHA LESH, Profe of Psychology at the University of California at Irvine. Wearing a purple afghan to hide the urge for jelly beans souffles, Norm looks up from her questionnaire and takes her reading glasses. She is sixty-one and full of pep. Ne to her are two long-haired graduate students, TAK and RYA

dialogues.speaker: DR. LESH
dialogues.text: Who are the members of the household involved? What are their ages?  38.

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: (monotone) Diane, my wife, she’s 31. Uh.. 32. My oldest daughter, Dana, 15. Robert, my son, he’s 9. And Carol Anne... (trails off)

dialogues.speaker: DR. LESH
dialogues.text: Yes... Carol Anne... Dr. Lesh writes five years old on the form.

dialogues.speaker: DR. LESH
dialogues.text: Has there been any publicity about the events?

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Absolutely no. Uh uh.

dialogues.speaker: DR. LESH
dialogues.text: Can you be reasonably sure of not letting any get started?

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: It’s the last thing in the world we want.

dialogues.speaker: DR. LESH
dialogues.text: Would your family welcome a serious investigation of the disturbances, by someone who could make first- hand observations?

dialogues.speaker: STEVE FREELING
dialogues.text: His eyes are dark shadows and the unflattering light feat the patches of stubble and parched lips. He speaks in hoa whispers, viewing these surroundings with great suspicion

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: Dr. Lesh. We don’t care about the disturbances... the pounding... the flashes or the music. We want you to find our little girl. FADE OUT.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dr. Les is mounting the stairs, followed by her two associates, TAK and RYAN. Steve is in the lead while Robb keeps his distance in the rear.

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: I should warn you we’ve had to lock off the room from the rest of the house. Robbie sleeps with us now. Dana, our oldest, spends a lot o time with... with friends.

dialogues.speaker: DR. LESH
dialogues.text: How many disturbances have you recorded in this room?

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: We don’t go in there any more.

dialogues.speaker: RYAN
dialogues.text: We’ll record any psychotronic energy or event.

dialogues.speaker: DR. LESH
dialogues.text: Ryan filmed an extraordinary episode during a case in Redlands.

dialogues.speaker: RYAN
dialogues.text: A child’s toy, small matchbox vehicle, rolled seven feet across a linoleum surface. The duration of the event was seven hours.

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: Seven hours for what?

dialogues.speaker: RYAN
dialogues.text: For the vehicle to complete the distance. This would never register on the naked eye, but I have the event on the time-lapse camera. ANGLE - CHILDREN’S BEDROOM DOOR Steve takes out a key and feels for the lock. Dr. Lesh an her assistants are looking around, checking out the hallw as Steve swings the door open.

dialogues.speaker: DR. LESH
dialogues.text: She casually looks in.  67 40. INT. CHILDREN’S BEDROOM - DAY

dialogues.speaker: INSIDE THE ROOM
dialogues.text: Inside is a junk pile of shattered furniture and toys. Th window is boarded up. Objects are in motion throughout th room... the bed is hopping about, records are flying, a l sails through. The clown is seated upside down on the boxspring as it spins. Children’s picture books flapping their covers like wings, cruise the upper reaches. A hors flies by. Finally, a spinning compass plays a record whil flying toward the roar of the room, creating an eerie mel

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All semblance of clinical cool is gone. They are blown aw

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Diane’s VOICE is heard over two shaking hands trying not spill a pot of coffee as it fills a cup. DIANE’S VOICE None of us have been much fun to be around. I guess you can tell I haven’t slept very much. Steve’s stayed home from work so much. He’s been really wonderful. Really. PAN UP from the shaking hands to Dr. Martha Lesh. She mus now use both hands, steady the coffee she’s just poured. assistants are in no better condition.

dialogues.speaker: DIANE
dialogues.text: She looks terrific. Her eyes are alert, hair combed back held with a bright yellow clip. She sips her coffee with steady hands and softly inquires.

dialogues.speaker: DIANE
dialogues.text: How long have you been investigating haunted houses?

dialogues.speaker: DR. LESH
dialogues.text: (embarrassed, backtracking) Well, Mrs. Freeling...

dialogues.speaker: DIANE
dialogues.text: Diane.  41.

dialogues.speaker: DR. LESH
dialogues.text: The determination as to whether your home is haunted is not a very easy one. At that moment the coffee pot moves by itself to the tabl edge but doesn’t spill. Dr. Lesh tries to overlook this, appearances sake.

dialogues.speaker: DR. LESH
dialogues.text: What I meant to say was this could very well be a poltergeist intrusion instead of the classic haunting.

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: There’s a difference? Two bright flashes of light distract Lesh and her associa

dialogues.speaker: RYAN
dialogues.text: Anybody see that?

dialogues.speaker: DIANE
dialogues.text: There’1l be two more in a few seconds. They always travel in pairs. Tak sits holding the camera with his mouth hung open. Les nudges him.

dialogues.speaker: DR. LESH
dialogues.text: Dr. Casey! Tak snaps out of it and looks down to adjust the lens set just as two more flashes go off in the air.

dialogues.speaker: DIANE
dialogues.text: Gotta be quicker than that around here.

dialogues.speaker: RYAN
dialogues.text: It’s electrical... you can smell the charge.

dialogues.speaker: DIANE
dialogues.text: You were saying poltergeists...

dialogues.speaker: DR. LESH
dialogues.text: (rattled) I was saying they are generally associated with an individual.  69 42. DR. LESH(cont'd) In the general vernacular, hauntings seems to be connected with an area... a house usually.

dialogues.speaker: TAK
dialogues.text: Poltergeist disturbances are of fairly short duration. Perhaps a couple of months. Hauntings can go on for years. Diane takes Steve’s hand, suddenly frightened.

dialogues.speaker: DIANE
dialogues.text: Are you telling me all this could just end at any time?

dialogues.speaker: DR. LESH
dialogues.text: Unless it’s a haunting. But as a rule, there seems to be no living person around whom haunting incidents revolve.

dialogues.speaker: DIANE
dialogues.text: Then we don’t have much time, Dr. Lesh. Because my daughter is alive somewhere in this house.

dialogues.speaker: THE FAMILY AND THE INVESTIGATORS
dialogues.text: Everyone is assembled around the console TV. Ryan has a Nakamichi cassette recorder on the coffee table and a pen microphone taped to the television speaker. Tak has erect his Nikon on a small aluminum tripod aimed at the screen plus two infrared heat seeking cameras and monitors which scan the entire living room. An electrostatic locator to measure ionization and a magnometer that measures magneti changes. Diane is holding Steve’s hand. Dana comes into the room with an overnight bag strapped around her shoulders.

dialogues.speaker: DIANE
dialogues.text: Dana, I’d like you to meet doctor...

dialogues.speaker: DANA
dialogues.text: (clipped) It’s getting dark, Mom. I gotta go. I’1l call you from Trudie’s.  43.

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: She won’t stay in the house after dusk.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: (disgusted) She’s got brains! Diane flips on the set. A local news station is finishing report when Diane turns to channel 27.

dialogues.speaker: DIANE
dialogues.text: We receive better on this channel but don’t ask me why. Dr. Lesh is thoroughly perplexed. She puts on her glasses Steve turns out the lamp and lights a cigarette. Diane squeezes her husband’s hand. The CAMERA PUSHES IN to the screen and millions of particles of white air. Diane turns the volume up and Ryan, wearing headsets, flinches, adjusting down the volume on his recorder.

dialogues.speaker: DIANE
dialogues.text: I'll call her. She says this so matter-of-factly that Dr. Lesh gasps. Di walks to the center of the living room, folds her hands i front of her, collecting her thoughts, takes a very deep breath and calls to the ceiling.

dialogues.speaker: DIANE
dialogues.text: It’s mommy, sweetheart. We want to talk to you. Baby, please answer Please talk to me, Carol Anne. Dr. Lesh looks quickly to Tak and Ryan for their human responses to this. Tak shrugs unnoticed. Ryan adjusts in chair and looks up at the ceiling. E. Buzz prances into the room, looking up as if following the heels of someone with a treat

dialogues.speaker: DR. LESH
dialogues.text: (to Tak breathlessly) Look at the dog. He sits up on his hind legs and begs to no one we see.

dialogues.speaker: DIANE
dialogues.text: Are you with us now? Can you say hello to Daddy? Say hello to Daddy, baby.  44.

dialogues.speaker: RYAN
dialogues.text: He tries hard not to smile. No matter. The suppressed lau is slapped away by what he now hears. Ryan grabs his head in two hands, pressing them hard to his ears.

dialogues.speaker: TAK
dialogues.text: (tight whisper) Good Lord... Everyone turns away from Diane and back to the TV. They strain their hearing, leaning forward, watching...

dialogues.speaker: VOICE
dialogues.text: (softly, sweetly, far away ) Hello, Daddy.

dialogues.speaker: DIANE
dialogues.text: Carol Anne. Where is this light?

dialogues.speaker: DR. LESH
dialogues.text: Tell her to stay away from it!

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: Tell her, Diane!!

dialogues.speaker: DIANE
dialogues.text: Sweetheart, the light is dangerous. Don’t go near it. Don’t look at the light. Tak speaks into Dr. Lesh’s ear.

dialogues.speaker: TAK
dialogues.text: I can’t believe it. It’s just a Zenith. But the voice could be C.B. broadcasting from somewhere in the house. I’m taking a look.

dialogues.speaker: DR. LESH
dialogues.text: It’s not a hoax.

dialogues.speaker: TAK
dialogues.text: We'll see. Tak takes off.  70 71 45. E. Buzz barks into the air twice and catches something in mouth. No sooner does Dr. Lesh catch this out of the corn of her eye when several midair electrical discharges illuminate the room.

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: What’s that?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From one of the flashes a number of tiny objects fall to carpeting. Jewelry, cameos, broaches, coins, watches, bot modern and pocket, along with many thin, wiry clips, spri the floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: E. Buzz immediately starts to sniff whatever it is.

dialogues.speaker: DR. LESH
dialogues.text: (to Ryan) Anything?

dialogues.speaker: RYAN
dialogues.text: (checking readouts) Nothing’s registering.

dialogues.speaker: VOICE
dialogues.text: Mommy... there’s somebody here.

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: (holding his head in his hands) Oh Jesus, this isn’t happening.

dialogues.speaker: VOICE
dialogues.text: Mommy... is it you?

dialogues.speaker: DIANE
dialogues.text: (fear enveloping her) Who is with you?

dialogues.speaker: VOICE
dialogues.text: (the voice is afraid) Somebody’s coming! !  72 73 46.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He goes room to room looking for pranksters. When he gets the active bedroom he hesitates, listens through the door pulls in his courage and turns the knob. Of course, the d is locked. Tak is never without a trick. He slips a file his utility belt and starts to jimmy the door. The lock g and Tak easily turns the knob, and lets out an agonizing SCREAM! He falls backward holding his side, rolling over over until he is at the top of the carpeted staircase.

dialogues.speaker: VOICE
dialogues.text: Help! No, no, no, no... The little voice hidden behind all the static SCREAMS.

dialogues.speaker: DIANE
dialogues.text: (screaming back) Run Carol Anne! Run away!!

dialogues.speaker: RYAN
dialogues.text: His eyes light up.

dialogues.speaker: MONITORS AND READBACKS
dialogues.text: Come to life and start registering wildly. Diane can’t stand the screams. She holds her ears, in tea now, imploring Dr. Lesh with her eyes.

dialogues.speaker: DIANE
dialogues.text: Carol Anne! Oh God!! Steve holds Diane to him, she pushes away and SCREAMS at ceiling.

dialogues.speaker: DIANE
dialogues.text: You fucking bastard, she’s just a baby!

dialogues.speaker: VOICE
dialogues.text: Mommy! Mommy !

dialogues.speaker: DIANE
dialogues.text: (screaming through tears to Dr. Lesh) Help her! Can’t you hear what’s happening?!  47. We HEAR soft FOOTSTEPS running across the ceiling and dow the wall. Two lamps are turned over and smash to pieces o the library table. We next HEAR colossal FOOTFALLS BOOMING in pursuit. A gus interior wind races through Diane’s clothes and hair. She SCREAMS in combined joy and horror.

dialogues.speaker: DIANE
dialogues.text: She just moved through me. My God, I felt her. I can smell her! She went through my soul! ! Diane runs back to Steve and grabs his shirt, pulling him her.

dialogues.speaker: DIANE
dialogues.text: Smell my clothes. It’s her. It’s her all over me. Steve smells and can’t believe it

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: It is her! The footsteps in pursuit grow louder. Diane turns to face sound. Dr. Lesh turns. Steve and Ryan turn. A perfectly f smell precedes an implosion of displaced air. Almost the sound of thunder, the impact is so great. Lesh, Diane and Steve blow backward, their clothes flapping in the gale a the force passes through each one of them and out the pic window that cracks in a dozen places but does not shatter

dialogues.speaker: DR. LESH
dialogues.text: (picking herself up) Have you ever heard of the term “teleportation”?

dialogues.speaker: DIANE
dialogues.text: Carol Anne!

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: That’s like when Mr. Spock beams up Captain Kirk on “Star Trek”.

dialogues.speaker: DR. LESH
dialogues.text: Just about. In a recent case, objects which disappeared from a house would be seen much later falling to the ground outside.

dialogues.speaker: DIANE
dialogues.text: Carol Anne doesn’t answer. Steve?  48.

dialogues.speaker: DR. LESH
dialogues.text: (to Steve) Where exactly do you suppose Carol Anne was playing before she vanished from sight?

dialogues.speaker: DIANE
dialogues.text: Her bedroom closet. And she wasn’t playing.

dialogues.speaker: DR. LESH
dialogues.text: Let’s go up there.

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: It won’t let you in.

dialogues.speaker: DR. LESH
dialogues.text: We’1ll just see about that. Lesh practically rolls up her sleeves and heads for the stairway, the rest following.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As they come around the corner they run smack into Tak, j coming down the last step, rubbing his side.

dialogues.speaker: DR. LESH
dialogues.text: What happened to you?

dialogues.speaker: TAK
dialogues.text: I was just about to check out the locked bedroom when... I don’t know... something took a bite out of me. Robbie gets very scared.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: You got bit?

dialogues.speaker: TAK
dialogues.text: That or the worst muscle spasm in the world.

dialogues.speaker: DR. LESH
dialogues.text: Roll up your shirt. Let’s have a look. Tak turns to face the hall light and untucks his shirt rolling it up. Then rolling up his T-shirt. Everyone crow in to see.

ANGLE - TAK’S STOMACH AND SIDE Teeth marks bear out Tak’s story. The unusual thing is, t bite wraps all the way around his side from kidneys to na A pink and partially bruised eleven-inch crescent impress

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: Eye level with it, his little mouth hanging open.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: Wow! Dr. Lesh takes a tentative step up the stairs then turns demonstratively.

dialogues.speaker: DR. LESH
dialogues.text: Let’s everybody spend the night down here.

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: Honey, I want you and Robbie to come with me. We’1ll sleep in town and tomorrow...

dialogues.speaker: DIANE
dialogues.text: (firm and quick) I’m not leaving Carol Anne.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: I don’t want to stay here anymore. This place’s got jaws.

dialogues.speaker: DIANE
dialogues.text: You take Robbie into town.

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: I’m not leaving you alone in this house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dr. Lesh has returned to the living room. She bends over grabs the apron off the couch and pulls. It folds out. A convertible bed.

dialogues.speaker: DR. LESH
dialogues.text: Blankets, pillows, sheets. Let’s have a slumber party.

dialogues.speaker: LATER THAT NIGHT
dialogues.text: Robbie and Diane are curled up together in the convertibl bed. Steve has put two chairs together and sleeps fitfull Dr. Lesh looks over Tak’s shoulder at the oscilloscope an electro hygrometer that is used for measuring changes in humidity.

dialogues.speaker: HALLWAY
dialogues.text: Ryan sits in a chair facing the staircase and the upper l of rooms His spectroscopic camera equipment is aiming directly up stairs. Lesh pats Ryan on the shoulders, he nearly jumps of his skin. They speak in whispers so as not to disturb others.

dialogues.speaker: RYAN
dialogues.text: Jesus, my heart.

dialogues.speaker: DR. LESH
dialogues.text: (whispering) Shhh. More thrills than grading papers, wouldn’t you say?

dialogues.speaker: RYAN
dialogues.text: (whispering) I can leave any time, you know. This isn’t the Army and you’re not my mother.

dialogues.speaker: DR. LESH
dialogues.text: (whispering) If push comes to shove, I bet I’1l beat you to the door. (indicating monitors) Any movement out of those things?

dialogues.speaker: RYAN
dialogues.text: (whispering) There’s been some ionization fluct. I’d like to make sure they’re not caused by humidity coming from structure leakage, but I’m not going up there to find out  76 51.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lesh goes to the console TV and, assuming everyone is asl she turns it off. In a very small voice Diane leans on he elbow.

dialogues.speaker: DIANE
dialogues.text: Please. Leave it on. Dr. Lesh smiles, it’s the first time we’ve seen her do th and it reminds Diane at once of her favorite story-book grandma who bakes cookies and knits comforters.

dialogues.speaker: DIANE
dialogues.text: She smiles back and motions for Dr. Lesh to come over.

dialogues.speaker: DIANE
dialogues.text: When things get quiet like now I can imagine how all this must look from you end. I’m really embarrassed.

dialogues.speaker: DR. LESH
dialogues.text: h, nonsense. I’1l1 tell you what is mbarrassing. My being here with ou nice people. Parapsychology sn’t something you master in. here are no certificates of raduation, no license to practice. ’m a professional psychologist who pends most of her time engaged in his ghostly hobby, which makes me, suppose, the most irresponsible ixty-one-year old woman I know. OHtMNH@AbP< OO

dialogues.speaker: DIANE
dialogues.text: You were so funny. Your hands were shaking a mile a minute.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Diane starts to giggle. It’s a release and Dr. Lesh joins her.

dialogues.speaker: DR. LESH
dialogues.text: It isn’t over. I’m perfectly terrified. It’s all these things we don’t understand. I feel like the protohuman, stepping of the forest primeval and seeing the moon for the first time. Throwing rocks at it.  52.

dialogues.speaker: DIANE
dialogues.text: You mean someday we’1ll understand these things?

dialogues.speaker: DR. LESH
dialogues.text: When it’s recognized for what it is. As any science. Understanding and sponsorship seem always to be one hundred years behind ridicule and doubt. Out of this experience, should we capture a high resolution photograph of a genuine manifestation Time Magazine will still put President Reagan on its next cover.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: If I got killed would I come back as a ghost and get stuck in the house like my sister?

dialogues.speaker: DIANE
dialogues.text: Your sister isn’t dead, Robbie.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: If I got killed could I visit her and show her how to get back here if you tied a rope around me and held it tight? Then somebody could come get me and we could move somewhere else?

dialogues.speaker: DR. LESH
dialogues.text: Some people believe that when you die your soul goes to heaven.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: When Grampa was dead I looked at him on the hospital bed and I was watchin’, but nothing went out of him.

dialogues.speaker: DIANE
dialogues.text: His soul was invisible. You couldn’t see it going to the sky.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: How come Grandpa isn’t on television with Carol Anne?

dialogues.speaker: DR. LESH
dialogues.text: Some people believe that when you die there is a wonderful light.  53. DR. LESH(cont'd) As bright as the sun but it doesn’t hurt to look into it. All the answers to all the questions you want to know are inside that light. And when you walk into it... you become a part of it forever. Now, some people die, but they don’t know they’re gone.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: They think they’re still alive?

dialogues.speaker: DR. LESH
dialogues.text: That’s right. Maybe they didn’t want to die. Maybe they weren’t ready. Maybe they hadn’t begun to live yet or lived a long, long time anyway, but wanted more life. They resist going into the light no matter how hard the light wants them. They hang around, watch TV, watch their friends grow up feeling all unhappy or jealous and those feelings are bad, they hurt And then some people just get lost on the way to the light. They need someone to lead them there.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: So some people get angry and throw things around like in my bedroom.

dialogues.speaker: DR. LESH
dialogues.text: Yes. Just like in school. There are people who are nice to you. And people who are mean.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: I got beat up once by three kids. They took my lunch money. Maybe they got hit by a truck and are upstairs right now.

dialogues.speaker: DIANE
dialogues.text: Let’s get some shuteye, whad’ya say, partner?

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: Goodnight, Mom. ‘Nite lady. ‘Nite, Dad. ‘Nite, E. Buzz. Robbie puts his head down on the pillow and Diane and Dr. Lesh share a warm look over him. Robbie sits back up sudd and looks at the TV set.  77 78

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: ‘Nite, Carol Anne.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Flanked by four banks of monitors and oscilloscopes, Tak’ stomach growls. He turns back looking over his shoulder a the kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: TAK
dialogues.text: He leans his chair back on its hind legs until his head reaches around the corner. Tak “pfffts” to Ryan. Ryan loo up from a Penthouse Magazine that he is studying by penli Tak gestures for Ryan to relieve him for a few minutes.

dialogues.speaker: BOTTOM OF STAIRCASE
dialogues.text: Tak gets up and Ryan sits down, getting right back into h Penthouse after a cursory look at the monitors and readou Ryan puts a Walkman over his ears and pops a Herbie Hanco tape in the cassette.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The refrigerator is the perfect target for Tak’s housebreaking skills. He turns once, looking over his shoulder before opening the Amana... the light inside bat everything in white. Tak takes out a salad bowl and noshe from that, but his chewing is too loud so he opts for a beautiful New York steak wrapped in cellophane. Placing the steak on the dark counter, Tak stuffs a chick leg into his mouth and searches the kitchen for a steak knife. He pulls his flashlight from his hip pocket and be pulling drawers... A new sound is added to his search. A CRAWLING GUSHY SOUN that bubbles and softly hisses. Tak turns and sees a shap moving along the counter where he put the steak. Approach Tak tilts his flashlight so the beam hits the object movi on the counter.

dialogues.speaker: KITCHEN COUNTER
dialogues.text: Tak’s POV The New York Steak is alive with CANCER! It actually craw over and over its own rampant cell growth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He starts to gag looking at it and realizes the chicken i still in his mouth. He spits it onto the floor and shines flashlight on top.

dialogues.speaker: CHICKEN LEG 78-C
dialogues.text: A thousand maggots crawl away from it into the dark corne of the kitchen. Tak starts to retch and flails into a sma powder room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tak turns the light on and retches into the sink

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ryan is reading the letters to Forum and hasn’t noticed t activity on the first readout. Slowly, the equipment come alive, purring softly, images vibrating. Ryan is too invo in Penthouse to notice the change. Herbie Hancock leaks f his headphones.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tak is catching his breath, his head lowered in frame. He stands up suddenly checking his complexion in the mirror.

dialogues.speaker: HIS MIRRORED REFLECTION
dialogues.text: His reflection is a ROTTING CORPSE, hair wild and streami his mouth open in a crazy way, teeth hanging by leathery threads, a funeral suit from the neck down. The bulb over the mirror CHANGES HUE from white to yellow orange to pink. In a burst of electricity it EXPLODES ove the sink as Tak wheels around showing us his LIVE IMAGE, TO NORMAL.

dialogues.speaker: RYAN
dialogues.text: Aware of nothing, reading, tapping his foot.  83 84 85 86 87 88 56.

dialogues.speaker: BEHIND RYAN
dialogues.text: Something is aglow at the top of the stairs. Something is starting to descend. Something ectoplasmic and blue-green.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The oscilloscopes are sine-waving like crazy. The remote cameras are triggered and click on. Tape machines roll automatically.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The substance is heading down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tak walks forward, his eyes riveted to the staircase. He feels in the dark until his hand touches Ryan’s head. Rya turns around to see who’s behind him and shines his flashlight up into Tak’s face.

dialogues.speaker: TAK
dialogues.text: Lit from below adds a demented aspect to Tak’s already terrified expression. Ryan looks immediately in the direc Tak is fixated... THE TOP OF THE STAIRS.

dialogues.speaker: BEHIND BOTH TAK AND RYAN
dialogues.text: The crawling mass coming down the stairs resembles a gian hand with long, searching fingers, flowing down the stair and heading right for the two technicians.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ryan stands and backs away two steps.

dialogues.speaker: TAK
dialogues.text: 89 90 91 57. He wants to scream out but cannot find the breath. The ai the room is suddenly thin and electrostatically charged.

dialogues.speaker: RYAN
dialogues.text: It’s manifesting! It’s manifesting! Look at the scope!

dialogues.speaker: TAK
dialogues.text: Watch the trip wires! Temperature’s dropping.

dialogues.speaker: RYAN
dialogues.text: Racial! !

dialogues.speaker: TAK
dialogues.text: Can you breathe?

dialogues.speaker: RYAN
dialogues.text: Can you run? I’m workin’ on it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The fingers are almost to the bottom. The smoking fingert suddenly rise straight up into the air like sky-writhing. Rising right up to the ceiling. Another tentacle of ectop seems to come forward. Larger and thicker than the rest a still growing, it studies the VTR and Panasonic camera, waltzing above it, hovering curiously close, then retract suddenly like a King Cobra.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dares to look at the monitor. His mouth drops open. He se something we don’t. His eyes shift back and forth between manifestation and the monitor. He bears his teeth to scre and...

dialogues.speaker: DR. LESH
dialogues.text: Her eyes open and she immediately pulls out her glasses.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
