dialogues.text: 92 58. Falls between two chairs trying to stand.

dialogues.speaker: DIANE
dialogues.text: Rising to her knees she looks out into the hall and hugs Robbie protectively.

dialogues.speaker: NIGHT 92
dialogues.text: Ectoplasmic mist wanders aimlessly, passing under tables chairs, circling lamps.

dialogues.speaker: DR. LESH
dialogues.text: (to Diane) Have you experienced this before?

dialogues.speaker: DIANE
dialogues.text: First time!

dialogues.speaker: DR. LESH
dialogues.text: Me too. At this moment every lightbulb in the room comes on. The brightness growing to blinding levels. Everyone covers th eyes.

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: (yelling) Smells like a short!

dialogues.speaker: DIANE
dialogues.text: (yelling) It’s going to explode! The hum of electrostatic charge races up the scales to wh sounds like feedback overload, then...

dialogues.speaker: FLASH FLASH
dialogues.text: Everything is dark again. The episode ended. The room is quiet. Dr. Lesh breaks the silence.

dialogues.speaker: DR. LESH
dialogues.text: Roll it back! Tak hits the rewind switch on both VTRs. Diane, Steve and Robbie all run to the display panel.  93 94 95 59.

dialogues.speaker: RYAN
dialogues.text: (like a kid) I think it recorded. I think we got one on tape. Yes. Yes... we got it recorded!!! WE MOVE from the faces of the Freelings and Lesh to:

dialogues.speaker: VIDEO MONITORS
dialogues.text: We SEE the empty hallway and staircase in black and white one screen. One the other a spectroscopic breakdown of co patterns in infrared. The picture on the screen becomes grainy, smoky. A bright glowly substance begins to form into tendrils that move d the stairs and very close to the cameras. The black and w monitor shows what the human eye captured. The color infr shows what the technology captured.

dialogues.speaker: DIANE
dialogues.text: MOVE IN TO HER as she watches the color monitor.

dialogues.speaker: MONITOR
dialogues.text: The smoky substance twists and melts and forms what appea to be the shape of a man’s back. The shape moves in front the CAMERA and we see what could be an OLD MAN looking ov his shoulder with a suspicious expression, and then walki past a little girl, not Carol Anne, holding a ball. She wanders through the living room as if lost. Suddenly, the living room is filled with manifestations. FOUR MEN in bu type coats, floppy hats, denim and boots face away from t CAMERAS, a WOMAN dressed in the style of the 1920’s moves through the room, tears on her face -- people of all ages descriptions wander aimlessly, lost and sad through the living room. No manifestation makes contact with any other. They don’t even seem to be aware that others exist -- an OLD WOMAN glances at the CAMERAS disinterestedly -- and a YOUNG BOY moves toward the CAMERA and evaporates. The screen suddenly becomes BLACK, filled by two glowing beams -- the beam pull back and we realize they are EYES scary old man. It is the face of pure chaotic horror. A vision of madness and murder.  96 97 60.

dialogues.speaker: ON DIANE AND ROBBIE
dialogues.text: She covers Robbie’s eyes and SCREAMS continuously, out of control, for this is the pit of her nightmare.

dialogues.speaker: DIANE
dialogues.text: That thing is in there with my baby! That thing! That thing!

dialogues.speaker: DR. LESH, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: My God! There are hundreds.

dialogues.speaker: FULL
dialogues.text: Steve is holding Diane now, stroking her hair until her SCREAMS turn into SOBS. Lesh and the technicians look on silently. Steve leads Diane and Robbie back into the livi room. Dr. Lesh takes out the two tapes and puts them into briefcase and locks it with a key.

dialogues.speaker: DUST PAN
dialogues.text: Crowded with a mixture of filled and decayed teeth from l evening’s hailstorm, Steve closes the trashcan and wipes hands against his shirt. The portable Tv is on, turned, a usual, to a static channel.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: Dressed to travel with a little suitcase in hand. At his is E. BUZZ on leash.

dialogues.speaker: DIANE
dialogues.text: Tell Grandma to call the very second you walk in.

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: Taxi’s here.

dialogues.speaker: DIANE
dialogues.text: Don’t be scared of the taxi man, he’s a friend of Daddy’s and mine.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: (agitated at all this fussing) I’m seven years old, gimme a break.

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: That’s what I like to hear. Let’s move out! ... you’re about to have yourself a real adventure.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: (acting grown up) I don’t need no more adventure. I need to get some sleep.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Diane and Steve watch Robbie and E. Buzz go out the door. Steve starts to follow, reaching out to help with the bag Robbie waves him off.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: I can do it myself. Bye.

dialogues.speaker: DIANE
dialogues.text: (tearful, but holding back) Bye, sweetheart. Call us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Robbie and E. Buzz climb into a taxi. It pulls away from curb.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dr. Lesh sorting through the brooches, stickpins, hail co and cameos. Brass buttons, pocket watches and cufflinks.

dialogues.speaker: DR. LESH
dialogues.text: This cameo. One hundred years old. Diane returns from the door and cocks her head to examine jewelry.

dialogues.speaker: DIANE
dialogues.text: Some haul, huh? (gestures upstairs) Maybe they fear a lawsuit and want an out of court settlement Dr. Lesh holds up a twist-o-flex digital wristwatch.  62.

dialogues.speaker: DR. LESH
dialogues.text: And then this enigma... probably a couple years old and not your husband’ s?

dialogues.speaker: DIANE
dialogues.text: He said it wasn’t.

dialogues.speaker: DR. LESH
dialogues.text: I’ve heard about jewelry or perfume disappearing from a vanity in one room later to reappear in another but... but this doesn’t fit into any construct I’ve ever experienced.

dialogues.speaker: DIANE
dialogues.text: Has anything lately?

dialogues.speaker: DR. LESH
dialogues.text: (smiles at this) No, I suppose not. Well, I’m off. I'll take these back to the lab along with the tapes... (disturbed) ...I’11 have to display these, you know. Steve enters the kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: Just please not on “Sixty Minutes”.

dialogues.speaker: DIANE
dialogues.text: Or... “That’s incredible”?

dialogues.speaker: DR. LESH
dialogues.text: I’m leaving Ryan with you. Tak won’t be coming back you know?

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: Yeah, he told me he wanted a day job.

dialogues.speaker: DR. LESH
dialogues.text: But he’s promised not to talk about this for several weeks. After that we’re all on our own. The front doorbell RINGS.

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: I’1l get it.  98 99 63.

dialogues.speaker: FRONT DOOR
dialogues.text: Steve opens it and is immediately uncomfortable. An older MAN, with gray hair and a pleasant smile, is standing the briefcase in hand.

dialogues.speaker: MR. TEAGUE
dialogues.text: We’ve missed you at the office, Steve. The fellows were worried so I took it upon myself to... (closely scrutinizes Steve’s appearance) Jesus, Steve, you look like shut. Aren’t you feeling any better. Steve just stands there like a schoolboy caught playing hooky.

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: Still a little weak... this particular strain of flu is not easy to get rid of. The minute you’re back on your feet... it uh... it’s back with you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TEAGUE’S POV Teague can see past Steve and into the living room and staircase. All sorts of scientific equipment is strung around. The big console TV is tuned to a static channel, is the kitchen portable, also visible from Mr. Teague’s vantage. Teague looks over Steve’s shoulder and Steve tries to sub block his view.

dialogues.speaker: MR. TEAGUE
dialogues.text: Looks like your cable is out there.

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: Cable? Yes, the cable. Yes. We’ve had no TV for several days.

dialogues.speaker: MR. TEAGUE
dialogues.text: Well, we should look into that. Is the entire block dark?  100 101 64.

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: Uh, no, no... just us. Just us. Behind Steve the couch moves across the room gently bumpi up against the baby grand piano which produces a musical vibration.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steve immediately steps outside with Mr. Teague and close the door behind him. The porch light comes on and even in bright daylight it glows to amazing intensity.

dialogues.speaker: MR. TEAGUE
dialogues.text: I see you have some electrical problems as well. wWhat’s screwed in there, a three hundred watt bulb? You afraid of prowlers or trying to attract every insect in Cuesta Verde? (he laughs)

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: My wife’s not feeling well either. She got a little of my bug.

dialogues.speaker: MR. TEAGUE
dialogues.text: Tell me something, are you happy here? I hope you don’t resent my leaping out to ask these things. We wouldn’t want to lose our best rep to either the flu or... other “opportunities”. All that software set up in your living room made me wonder whether you've got a little something going on the side.

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: Just hobbies. Popular Mechanics.

dialogues.speaker: MR. TEAGUE
dialogues.text: Are you up to a little ride? I want to show you something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Diane hangs desperately onto any tangible reality. She mo carefully through the house, cleaning up. When she passes Carol Anne and Robbie’s room Diane hesitates. She listens through the door. She knocks softly and prays.  102 103 65.

dialogues.speaker: DIANE
dialogues.text: (lightly) Hello. Anyone home? (she raps softly) Carol Anne? Diane slips her hand down to the doorknob. Knowing it is always locked she feels safe in trying it -- the knob tur in her hand. Tak never locked up after his episode. Diane GASPS and jumps back. As much as she wants to, Diane won’ in. She backs into her own bedroom and shuts the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She turns and sees the bed is not made. Diane pulls off t covers and the sheets, making them ready for the washing machine. Dust rises off the bed and Diane SNEEZES. As she tilts her head back for a second sneeze she freezes looki at the wall over her head. The sneeze never materializes.

dialogues.speaker: THE WALL
dialogues.text: The STAIN HAS GROWN. It is three feet in diameter and sha like a black rose. Little black, wiggly lines, like veins scribble away from the black pistil in all directions. Di flinches and steps away from it. She sees a picture on he other wall and determines to hang it over the stain.

dialogues.speaker: MR. TEAGUE
dialogues.text: I’m so very proud of this place. Steve and Teague stand on a hill overlooking the entire Cuesta Verde Estates. Teague’s Bronco sits off to one sid

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: I’ve been up here once or twice. Diane calls it Vanity Point.

dialogues.speaker: MR. TEAGUE
dialogues.text: So who’s to say an artist shouldn’t step back from his easel to admire the sum of his parts?

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: (almost forgetting his ordeal for a few seconds of mental freedom)  66. STEVEN(cont 'd) When they build our model home, there was nothing down there. Just freshly turned earth and a lotta wooden stakes and miles and miles of string.

dialogues.speaker: MR. TEAGUE
dialogues.text: One of your children was born in your house.

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: (not smiling now) Carol Anne.

dialogues.speaker: MR. TEAGUE
dialogues.text: I understand she’s missed a lot of school lately. Trask’s daughter’s in the same nursery class. She have the flu as well?

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: Yeah, we’ve all got the same thing.

dialogues.speaker: MR. TEAGUE
dialogues.text: I’m sorry. I didn’t see her.

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: Oh, she’s around.

dialogues.speaker: MR. TEAGUE
dialogues.text: Are you?

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: (his mind in the valley, snaps out of it) Am I what?

dialogues.speaker: MR. TEAGUE
dialogues.text: Are you thinking of leaving Cuesta Verde?

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: (dazed) I can’t believe how a day can be so beautiful. You wonder how anyone can have a problem in the world on a day like this.

dialogues.speaker: MR. TEAGUE
dialogues.text: (kicking up some sod with his heel) Nice spot for a bay window, wouldn’t you agree?  104 67.

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: If you’re living up here, great. Wouldn’t be so terrific from the valley, looking up at a lotta houses cutting into these hills.

dialogues.speaker: MR. TEAGUE
dialogues.text: You don’t have to live in the valley any more.

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: What are you getting at?

dialogues.speaker: MR. TEAGUE
dialogues.text: Phase Five is going up right where we’re standing. This could be your master bedroom suite. That could be your view. You interested?

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: Mr. Teague, that’s a very generous offer but I’m not a developer.

dialogues.speaker: MR. TEAGUE
dialogues.text: You’re responsible for 42% of sales, almost half of what we’re looking at down there. Almost seventy million dollars of dwellings and property. Maybe a generation of security that no one can put a price tag on. We should have made you a full partner three years ago... I don’t want to lose you now. Steve doesn’t know what to think. So much is piling up so suddenly. It’s a golden opportunity that two weeks ago wo have meant a Hawaiian vacation and days of happiness and celebration. Steve turns around to take in the view.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This whole conversation has taken place just inches outsi quiet little cemetery with picket fences and both ancient recent headstones. Steve scratches and gestures to the three-acre memorial p

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: Not much room for a pool.  68.

dialogues.speaker: MR. TEAGUE
dialogues.text: We own the land. We’ve already made arrangements to relocate the cemetery.

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: Can you do that? I mean, isn’t it rather... I don’t know... sacrilegious?

dialogues.speaker: MR. TEAGUE
dialogues.text: Don’t worry about it. It’s not an ancient tribal burial ground. It’s just... people. Besides, we’ve done it before.

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: When?

dialogues.speaker: MR. TEAGUE
dialogues.text: In ‘76. Right down there.

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: (struck) Cuesta Verde?

dialogues.speaker: MR. TEAGUE
dialogues.text: All three hundred acres. It was quite a job, let me tell you.

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: (to himself, his mind racing) I never heard anything about it.

dialogues.speaker: MR. TEAGUE
dialogues.text: Well, it’s not something you go around advertising on billboards and the sides of buses. Steve is speechless. He looks back and forth between the existing cemetery and Cuesta Verde Estates below.

dialogues.speaker: MR. TEAGUE
dialogues.text: What are you worried about? Relatives and friends can visit their loved ones at Broxton Memorial Park. It’s only five minutes further out for Christ’s sake.  105 106 69.

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: (quietly, to himself) Five minutes. I guess that’s no great hardship. I suppose that would be okay.

dialogues.speaker: MR. TEAGUE
dialogues.text: Okay with whom?

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: Whomever might complain.

dialogues.speaker: MR. TEAGUE
dialogues.text: Nobody’s complained up til now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Students mill about between classes. It’s a beautiful day Irvine.

dialogues.speaker: DR. LESH AND A SENIOR ADVISOR, ANTHONY FARROW.
dialogues.text: They are sitting in an empty lecture hall. Monitors are everywhere. Several people are filing out. Lesh is exhaus Apparently she’s been through quite an ordeal. Anthony Fa is twenty years old than Dr. Lesh, which puts him into hi early eighties. He puts a comforting arm around her and sits on the desk smiling like the wizened sage he is.

dialogues.speaker: FARROW
dialogues.text: In a word? He hands her back the video tapes.

dialogues.speaker: DR. LESH
dialogues.text: In a word.

dialogues.speaker: FARROW
dialogues.text: Too graphic!

dialogues.speaker: DR. LESH
dialogues.text: It was the episode as it occurred.

dialogues.speaker: FARROW
dialogues.text: Perhaps.  70.

dialogues.speaker: DR. LESH
dialogues.text: Oh, Tony... you too?

dialogues.speaker: FARROW
dialogues.text: I so wish to accept what I saw. I’m only steps away from the old wooden bridge myself. To believe that something exists on the other side would be like a warm light in the window.

dialogues.speaker: DR. LESH
dialogues.text: Perhaps if tendrils of ectoplasm were all that showed up?

dialogues.speaker: FARROW
dialogues.text: Better.

dialogues.speaker: DR. LESH
dialogues.text: A smoky shape lasting merely an instant.

dialogues.speaker: FARROW
dialogues.text: Even better.

dialogues.speaker: DR. LESH
dialogues.text: Nothing on tape at all... only sounds, rappings, a sigh.

dialogues.speaker: FARROW
dialogues.text: You’d still be answering questions. They’d all want to go back to the house tonight. You gave them too much, Martha. Too much too soon. Nothing was left to the imagination. This isn’t a science yet. It’s still a sideshow and your troubadours were not in their make- up.

dialogues.speaker: DR. LESH
dialogues.text: And these? What do you make of these? She gestures to the dozens of jewelry pieces on the desk. Farrow picks up a beautiful brooch. He holds it up to the light.

dialogues.speaker: FARROW
dialogues.text: It’s the real McCoy, that’s one thing for certain.  71. Farrow pins the brooch on Lesh’s sweater and takes an ant ring, placing it on her finger.

dialogues.speaker: FARROW
dialogues.text: Dear Martha. May we cross that bridge together someday? May all we believe be true. May we picnic in the clouds. Dr. Lesh starts to laugh and punches Farrow on his leg.

dialogues.speaker: DR. LESH
dialogues.text: You old con artist. If only you were fifty years younger.

dialogues.speaker: FARROW
dialogues.text: Let me give you some advice. Secret a few of those gems. Come out of this with something in your pocket. The National Enquirer pays more for inventing what we must bust our rumps investigating and for what?

dialogues.speaker: DR. LESH
dialogues.text: Okay, pops! I’m making you the accessory in this crime. She picks out a set of earrings and stuffs them into her change purse. Farrow laughs as Dr. Lesh starts to fold up napkin containing the stones and jewelry. Suddenly Farrow stops her, reaching for something in the pile.

dialogues.speaker: FARROW
dialogues.text: This is interesting. He picks up a thin, wiry clip that looks like it could be dog muzzle for a miniature poodle.

dialogues.speaker: FARROW
dialogues.text: Did this teleport with everything else?

dialogues.speaker: DR. LESH
dialogues.text: Yes, I picked it up myself. Why? He turns it over in his hand.

dialogues.speaker: FARROW
dialogues.text: It’s a staple, a clamp for the jaw.

dialogues.speaker: DR. LESH
dialogues.text: Not something you’d wear to the masquerade ball.  72.

dialogues.speaker: FARROW
dialogues.text: No, but you would wear it to your own funeral. It’s a mortician’s trick. It prevents the mouth from suddenly dropping open when the body is in repose. It discourages a great deal of embarrassment and... fainting.

dialogues.speaker: DR. LESH
dialogues.text: (with a shiver she looks at her watch) Oh darn, I promised I’d be back before dark.

dialogues.speaker: FARROW
dialogues.text: Martha, my dear. Why don’t you let Tangina have a go?

dialogues.speaker: DR. LESH
dialogues.text: (sourly) I was afraid you’d suggest that. Tangina’s so... melodramatic.

dialogues.speaker: FARROW
dialogues.text: Yes. But she’s a house-cleaner and right now with what you tell me about that little girl, I think it’s high time you brought out your big guns.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This time we are framing the first row of headstones, PUS PAST them to the warm suburban glow that reaches for mile into the hills, joined by a sprinkling of stars on this moonlit night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We are following Steve and Diane. They seem to be gazing as they walk through their home. CAMERA WIDENS to reveal and Lesh ahead of the Freelings. They appear to be follow something, also looking down at their feet. CAMERA PANS D expecting to find E. Buzz at the head of this train. Instead... We meet TANGINA BARRONS, astrologist, clairvoyant, midget  73. She is dressed in a California Hawaiian print dress, wear her hair in a beehive, dons aviator sunglasses and casual sips coffee from a mug as she explores the Freeling home. Tangina stops and looks at her followers. She speaks with very polite Southern accent.

dialogues.speaker: TANGINA
dialogues.text: Would you all mind hangin’ back. You’re jamming my frequencies. They oblige and Tangina waddles her way down the hall and the stairs unaccompanied.

dialogues.speaker: DR. LESH
dialogues.text: I know what you’re thinking. You’1l have to take my word on this. She’s cleaned many houses. Her gifts are well documented at the parapsychology laboratory at Duke University, University of Virginia, the... Diane is becoming more and more distraught over something

dialogues.speaker: DIANE
dialogues.text: We haven’t heard a word from Carol Anne since last night.

dialogues.speaker: TANGINA, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Why is this door locked, Mr. Freeling? Steve looks up the stairs, he’s about to answer but inste decides to concentrate. A pause.

dialogues.speaker: DIANE
dialogues.text: Answer her.

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: (softly) I am. Tangina appears at the upper rail and looks down between banister posts.

dialogues.speaker: TANGINA
dialogues.text: I am addressing the living?

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: (giving up) I’m sorry. That’s the room my son and daughter occupy.  109 74.

dialogues.speaker: DR. LESH
dialogues.text: We believe it’s the heart of the house.

dialogues.speaker: TANGINA
dialogues.text: This house has many hearts. Tangina turns away and continues her search.

dialogues.speaker: LIVING ROOM
dialogues.text: Steve turns to Diane and Lesh and Ryan, pulling them into circle of whispers.

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: (whispering) I was trying to answer with my mind. She couldn’t hear me. I thought you said Tangina Barrons was an extraordinary clairvoyant. From far away and well out of earshot Tangina answers.

dialogues.speaker: TANGINA, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: (upstairs) I am. I just don’t like trick answers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The CAMERAS are all set up. The Zenith console is now the centerpiece of this room. The rest of the furniture has b piled against the walls although we’re not sure if this i Diane’s work or early poltergeist disturbances. Tangina s herself on the video monitor and smiles into the CAMERA. waves and watches herself waving on the monitor. She make funny face and gets a huge thrill at seeing it in black a white. Diane and Steve stand divorced from this. They hav become bit players as Tangina takes center stage.

dialogues.speaker: TANGINA
dialogues.text: Can you make my face look bigger? Thinking this is a scientific request, Ryan ZOOMS IN fill the monitors with Tangina.

dialogues.speaker: TANGINA
dialogues.text: Look at me for cryin’ out loud! You’d never suspect I was just a teeny little thing, would ya?  75.

dialogues.speaker: DR. LESH
dialogues.text: Tangina, could we get on with this please? Tangina pulls out a lipstick and freshens her makeup, all while watching herself in the monitor.

dialogues.speaker: TANGINA
dialogues.text: I’ve never been on TV before. She steps back and looks into the CAMERA. She adds to her already thick Texas accent. The melodrama gushes out of h

dialogues.speaker: TANGINA
dialogues.text: Yes, it was me all the time, not that fussy harlot from the office. I shot J.R. Ewing! I blew his little pecker right into the gulf of Mexico. I... (embarrassed) Oh, I swore on television. No one is laughing. Especially Diane and Steve. They are rather appalled. Tangina immediately pulls back. She beco an adult again and walks into the center of the room.

dialogues.speaker: TANGINA
dialogues.text: (to Diane) Honey, c’mere and give me your hand. Diane hesitates and looks over at Dr. Lesh.

dialogues.speaker: TANGINA
dialogues.text: I’m not gonna bite’cha. Diane slowly walks to Tangina and reaches down with her h

dialogues.speaker: TANGINA
dialogues.text: C’mon down here. You’re gonna give me whiplash lookin’ up at you. Diane smiles and kneels. She is eye level with Tangina.

dialogues.speaker: TANGINA
dialogues.text: (softly, just for Diane to hear) Your daughter is alive and in this house. The tears come immediately. Diane breaks down, sobbing, t first confirmation of her own belief from the outside.  76. Tangina hugs her, patting the back of Diane’s head reassuringly. Steve starts to come over to comfort but Tangina waves him off and mouths...

dialogues.speaker: TANGINA
dialogues.text: a glass of water.

dialogues.speaker: DR. LESH
dialogues.text: She sits down and smiles. Relieved, looks to Ryan. Ryan i filming it.

dialogues.speaker: TANGINA
dialogues.text: (to Dr. Lesh) Where was the last incident of “biolocation”? Dr. Lesh points to the air just above Tangina’s head.

dialogues.speaker: TANGINA
dialogues.text: I have my strongest feeling, the point of origin is inside the child’s closet. Upstairs.

dialogues.speaker: DIANE
dialogues.text: (through tears) Yes. I feel that too.

dialogues.speaker: TANGINA
dialogues.text: (to Diane) Now, honey. Are you gonna be real strong for me? For your daughter? I can do absolutely nothing without your faith in this world and your love for the children.

dialogues.speaker: DIANE
dialogues.text: I will. Believe me, I will.

dialogues.speaker: TANGINA
dialogues.text: Will you do anything I say? Even if it comes contrary to your beliefs as a human bein’ and as a Christian?

dialogues.speaker: DIANE
dialogues.text: Oh yes. Please.

dialogues.speaker: TANGINA
dialogues.text: (cupping Diane’s face and bringing their eyes together )  110 77. TANGINA(cont 'd) Then let’s get on our feet and go get your daughter. Diane laugh-cries and rises. Tangina starts to rise but t realizes...

dialogues.speaker: TANGINA
dialogues.text: (brightly) Oh... I am standin’.

dialogues.speaker: TELEVISION CONSOLE
dialogues.text: Static snow grates again on our nerves.

dialogues.speaker: FULL
dialogues.text: Diane is in her self-appointed position, the center of th room awaiting notice from Tangina Barrons who checks thro a lot of items laid out on a tablecloth on the living roo floor.

dialogues.speaker: TANGINA
dialogues.text: (checklisting) Towels, red ribbon handkerchiefs... How’re the tennis balls coming? Ryan and Dr. Lesh are painting numbers on each of six ten balls and then carefully signing their names. String hang across the ceiling and to each wall coming together in th air six feet above the floor to form a square. Steve runs in with several pounds of rope slung around hi shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: It’s all I could find.

dialogues.speaker: TANGINA
dialogues.text: It'll do. How’s the bath water doin’?

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: I shut it off. It’s ready.

dialogues.speaker: TANGINA
dialogues.text: Then I don’t see any reason why we shouldn’t get started. (to Diane) All right, honey. Call out to her.  78. In the low light of the living room, Diane stands in the center like a frightened contestant about to audition a s She says a prayer under her breath and looks skyward.

dialogues.speaker: DIANE
dialogues.text: Carol Anne... Carol Anne... It’s Mommy. Can you hear me tonight?

dialogues.speaker: TV CONSOLE
dialogues.text: Nothing.

dialogues.speaker: DIANE
dialogues.text: Carol Anne. Can you tell Mommy hello?

dialogues.speaker: TV CONSOLE
dialogues.text: Nothing.

dialogues.speaker: TANGINA
dialogues.text: Her eyes are closed and her breathing becomes irregular. licks at her dry lips and motions to Diane.

dialogues.speaker: TANGINA
dialogues.text: Try again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is raining and Diane is instantly soaked as she backs looking at the house SCREAMING.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Diane’s feet lose her footing in the mud and she falls in the shallow end of the unfinished swimming pool, sliding the way down the wet mud to the puddle in the deep end. THE POOL LIGHTS COME ON. Backlighting the rain and Diane’ flopping actions as she regains her balance is the quagmi Then, A GUSHING BUBBLE EXPLODES next to her in the mud. S stares at it as a second bubble bursts revealing within i the leathery face of a corpse, in its burial clothes, ris like a weed straight out of the gushing mud. Diane SCREAM and backs into ANOTHER FACE who’s mouth stretches open revealing tiny wire jaw clamps that make popping SOUNDS l a jew’s harp. With a terrible SLURP, the top of a metal coffin pushes out of the mud, its lid hinged open, tossin bones and dirt and burial jewelry all over Diane. INT. CHILDREN’S BEDROOM - NIGHT 153

dialogues.speaker: CAROL ANNE
dialogues.text: She is SCREAMING WILDLY. A white hot light erasing her features as she once again fights the phantom wind that begins to suck the room toward the closet.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: Wrestling on the floor with the clown. He tears the stuff from its middle, shredded bits of white cotton flying at terrifying speed toward the closet opening.

dialogues.speaker: THE CLOSET 153-A
dialogues.text: The closet is becoming a living, terrifying organism as b of flesh grow like moss along the squared off door frame. Fatty tissues form, veins escape into the soft pink skin until we are looking into a living mouth, all gims and blinding light and at the very back, a pale yellow esopha that spirals to abysmal depths.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Some sort of seismic upheaval is forcing dead things up f the ground in even greater numbers. Diane is climbing up steep, slick incline toward the metal ladder at the shall end. With every couple of steps to safety, she slips back the rain, turning back to see the black tie crowd that aw her. Diane turns back reaching out her hand to dig in dee when... ANOTHER HAND GRABS HERS. Diane shrieks and looks into the face of Ben Tuthill from next door.

dialogues.speaker: TUTHILL
dialogues.text: Look at that! Look at that!! Look in your pool, my God!! Mrs. Tuthill runs over in her night clothes.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. TUTHILL
dialogues.text: Your children. Listen. What sort of sound is that? Ethereally, the SCREAMS from Carol Anne and Robbie sound almost angelic in the rain.

dialogues.speaker: I_HAVE TO GET THEM OUT
dialogues.text: She pulls away from Tuthill and races back inside the hou Ben starts to follow but then Mrs. Tuthill stops him.

dialogues.text: Don’t go in there! Don’t ever go in there!  155 156 157 101.

dialogues.text: Diane hits the staircase and races up. The door to the children’s room is shut and ultra-bright light is streami from under the jamb. Diane opens it and is immediately su in. INT. dialogues.text: Robbie reaches out with his one hand and Diane tries to w her way against the rip to get into position. She looks a the closet.

dialogues.text: It sucks harder and Robbie and Carol Anne’s beds start to move toward the hot pink opening. Diane lurches the final inch and grabs Robbie’s little wrist with both hands.

dialogues.speaker: TAKE_IT
dialogues.text: Robbie reaches for Carol Anne, who reaches out to Robbie. They are but inches apart.

dialogues.speaker: CLOSET
dialogues.text: One last powerful inhale and the two beds shoot out from under the children just as Robbie grabs his sister’s hand Diane pulls them from the room.

dialogues.text: Diane drags her children down the stairs and toward the f door. The staircase is rolling as in an earthquake, knock them off balance and onto the landing face down. Diane se the front door through a sudden cut over her left eye. Sh leads the children to it slow in motion as a phenomenally intense headwind tries to prevent their escape.  158 159 160 161 162 163 164 102.

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: You moved the cemetery! But you left the bodies didn’t you! You son- of-a-bitch! You left the bodies and only moved the headstones! !

dialogues.text: Diane, carrying Carol Anne, and Robbie come running from back yard. Two coffins pop up in their path. They dodge t cascading bodies and scramble towards the station wagon.

It flies open and a hideous corpse lurches across the sidewalk at Teague. He falls backwards into a hole, the corpse landing on top of him. Teague tries to scream but only night breath gushes out.
